bibl.title: Jap Military Leaders Block Birth Control, Says Mrs. Sanger

doc.headNote: Sanger made this statement in El Paso while on a travel layover.

docBody.head: Jap Military Leaders Block Birth Control, Says Mrs. Sanger

p.q: The people of Japanhave been victimized by their military leaders even more than the people of Germanyis the opinion of Mrs. Margaret Sanger. Mrs. Sanger, stopping with friends in El Pasobetween planes today, told of her visit to Japan in 1937.

docBody.p: I was on my way to Chinaat the invitation of Madam Chiang Kai-Shek, but never got any further than TokyoTokyo because of the China-Japanese war,she said. A Japanese woman told me that the country’s social-minded liberals realized that their population increase must be curtailed or they would be enemies of the whole world. For years these liberals had been crying for population control and the acquisition of a modern social system, but the militaristic party had become so firmly entrenched that these people simply went to jail for their efforts.

p.q: Mrs. Sanger’s friend, Baroness Ishimoto, the leading Japanese liberal, has been in jail for years, and none of her friends can get any word from her. She has visited Mrs. Sanger in the United States, and Mrs. Sanger visited her in Japan.

docBody.p: The birth rate in Japan is about two million a year, and one million of these survive, Mrs. Sanger said.You can see that putting that many people on those tiny islands is like putting several families in a very small house. Their policy of aggression is exactly the same as if the inhabitants of the overcrowded house went next door and took charge of three or four rooms and helped themselves to the groceries. It’s the same with Italy. For Germanythere is absolutely no excuse. Germany has had the opportunity for centuries to be civilized and to make her population conform to her boundaries.

p.q: Mrs. Sanger is en route to Palm Beachto visit her son, Stewart Sanger, a doctor now in the Army. He is a specialist in tropical diseases. Her other son, Grant, is also a doctor now in the Navy. He is a surgeon.
Head of the post-war planning committee of the Planned Parenthood League of America, Mrs. Sanger’s interest in the possibilities of the post-war world is high.

docBody.p: Since the leading scientists of Americaare on our board, Planned Parenthood will certainly have a representative on whatever final post-war planning council is formed,she said. H.G. Wellssaid the most intelligent people of America are on our board, and he’s right.

p.q: Mrs. Sanger was enthusiastic in her praise of the El Paso Mothers’ Health Center, of which Mrs. Percy W. Pogson Jr., is president.

docBody.p: I am proud of the work you have done here, Mrs. Sanger said. It will take just that kind of perseverance and devotion to make the post-war world a fit place in which to live. The American people have become somewhat timid in the last few years and have listened too much to the words of vociferous minorities, but this group in El Paso proves how unnecessary that is.

p.q: The years of hardship, persecution and misunderstanding through which Mrs. Sanger has passed in her efforts to improve the lot of humanity have left no mark, unless it be her deep understanding and genuine gentleness. She is one liberal thinker who has not become discouraged with the failure of others to catch up with her, and has maintained her reverence and flexibility of mind.

docBody.p: Children are the most important things in the world,she said, And it is our foremost duty to improve the conditions under which our children and our children’s children must live.
